thread.title: Melbourne Careers Expo to go ahead despite tax debt, says director Bottazzi
thread.title_full: Melbourne Careers Expo to go ahead despite tax debt, says director Bottazzi

author: Sarah Danckert
title: Melbourne Careers Expo to go ahead despite tax debt, says director Bottazzi
text:
Robert Bottazzi managed King Street strip club Showgirls Bar 20 before branching out into careers expos.
Melbourne Career Expo is expected to go ahead later this month even as the tax office chases the company behind the major event and its sole director Robert Bottazziâ€‹ over an unpaid debt.
Mr Bottazzi, better known for his stint managing Showgirls Bar 20 and as a former director of listed brothel owner Planet Platinum, told Fairfax Media he had brokered a payment plan with the Australian Taxation Office three months ago.
Look, there was an investment property that didn't quite go to plan but that's since be rectified and everything is back on track.
Robert Bottazzi, Expo director "We've made a payment plan and we've been doing it for the last three months now. Everything has been paid and everything is going according to plan," he said.
Melbourne Careers Expo has been slapped with a $200,000-plus tax bill Photo: Gabriele Charotte
Despite that, the ATO has filed a winding up application in the federal court earlier this month.
Mr Bottazzi said that action was linked to the payment plan agreement: "To just make it sure happens, they filed that."
Mr Bottazzi's business partner Nicole Capper, who was managing director of Melbourne Career Expo until 2013 and is still listed on the expo's website as a contact person, declined to comment.
Illustration: John Shakespeare.
Court documents filed by the ATO show it has asked for the court to wind up against Melbourne Careers Expo Pty Ltd and appoint PPB Advisory as liquidators. The matter will be heard on August 26.
Mr Bottazzi assured Fairfax Media the exhibition would still run from July 24 to July 26.
"The expo is still going. The Exhibition buildings have been paid, everyone's been paid. It's definitely going ahead 100 per cent," he said.
A former business partner of Joe Trimble, the nephew of dead crime lord Bob Trimbole, Mr Bottazzi denied he was in any financial strife, adding the debt was the result of a property deal gone wrong.
The ATO issued a statutory demand against Melbourne Careers Expo in April after it failed to pay its tax bill.
According to the ATO's claim against Melbourne Careers Expo file on July 6: "The defendant failed to pay the amount of debt demanded" within 21 days of the April demand.
Mr Bottazzi claimed he had not missed a payment and had an agreement in place to pay back the tax office a certain amount every week and a lump sum at in late August. Mr Bottazzi also said that he did not owe the ATO $206,499.95.
"It's not $200,000. Some of the amounts are being negotiated at the moment with tax penalties and interest and so forth. Look, there was an investment property that didn't quite go to plan but that's since be rectified and everything is back on track," Mr Bottazzi said.
The ATO declined to comment on specific tax matters, however, the tax office's website in regards to wind up actions states: "We will take action to wind up a company if it has failed to pay its debts and we have not been able to make a suitable payment arrangement."
A spokeswoman for the Melbourne Exhibition and Convention Centre declined to confirm whether the event was going ahead, referring Fairfax Media's inquiries to Melbourne Careers Expo.
